qas.question: Peter J. Wallison believes that the huge number of these loans led to the financial crisis?
What type downpayments do substandard loans generally have?
According to Peter J. Wallison, why did the U.S. residential housing bubble led to financial crisis?

answers.text: it was supported by a huge number of substandard loans

qas.question: Other countries had large residential housing bubbles that deflated during what years?
Peter J. Wallison's conclusions regarding the financial crisis are not in agreement with this economist's views?

context: Countering <a4_0>Krugman<a4_0/>, Peter J. Wallison wrote: "It is not true that every bubble—even a large bubble—has the potential to cause a financial crisis when it deflates." Wallison notes that other developed countries had "large bubbles during the <a3_0>1997–2007<a3_0/> period" but "the losses associated with mortgage delinquencies and defaults when these bubbles deflated were far lower than the losses suffered in the United States when the 1997–2007 [bubble] deflated." According to Wallison, the reason the U.S. residential housing bubble (as opposed to other types of bubbles) led to financial crisis was that <a2_0>it was supported by a huge number of <a0_0>substandard<a0_0/> loans<a2_0/> – generally with <a1_0>low or no downpayments<a1_0/>.
